param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This is the longslit acquisition template for science observation of a point source centered in the middle of CCD2. It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port. The class has been set to 'Acquisition'.
The first step is an imaging exposure with the CCD binned 2x2 (CCD2)
The second step is a 20s image (offset P=10 arcsec, which is reverted in the 3rd step) through the slit that is used to measure the slit center with the CCD binned 1x1 and the ROI set to Central Stamp (300x300 pixels FOV).
The third step is an image through the slit that is used to confirm the offsets have well centered the science target within the slit , again the CCD is binned 1x1 with ROI Central Stamp (300x300 pixel FOV)
The user will need to adjust the exposure time to be appropriate for a given target. Use the ITC to find the exposure time needed. A S/N>=10 is recommended for acquisition observations. The exposure time of the slit image (second step) should be left as defined at 20 seconds.

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
Take first 2 images (wait for astigmatism to be < ~0.2 especially if using the image to judge IQ). cl> gacq 1
Take the image through slit to confirm/tweak centering. **MUST TAKE THIS IMAGE.** cl> gacq 3 (when the gacq asks you if you want to use the previously measured slit center say yes)
Need another? cl> gacq 4 (when the gacq asks you if you want to use the previously measured slit center say yes)
---
Details: 1 = source image (CCD2) 2 = 20s image through slit used for measuring the slit center (STAMP) should be found automatically by gacq the first time, and afterward the recorded slit center should be used. can specify to use this slitimage specifically in the second and third iterations manually if you get into trouble by specifying slitimage=2 on the gacq command line (eg. gacq 3 slitimage=2) 3 = source through slit (STAMP) 4 = source through slit (STAMP)

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This template shows a longslit science observation with GCAL flats mixed in.
It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
An offset sequence nods the target along the slit by +/- 15 arcsec. A GMOS-S iterator dithers the grating spectrally in 2 wavelength settings in order to cover the gap between the CCDs and get full wavelength coverage.
The required observations for a Longslit program include:
Longslit: Acquisition Longslit: Science
and the Baseline Calibrations include:
Longslit: CuAr Longslit: Standard Acquisition Longslit: Standard with GCALflats Longslit: Standard CuAr Longslit: Twilight flat

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
- This is a longslit CuAr arc, to be taken as the baseline calibration during the day (class=Daytime Calibration).
- The guide star has been removed from the target component, since the telescope will be stationary at zenith for this observation.
- The Translation Stage has been set to "Follow in Z Only" since the telescope is stationary and the Telescope Control System may not be up when this observation is taken.
- The readout is "fast" in order to save time.
- Because this CuAr is for the science target calibration the ROI is set to Full Frame.
- It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
- The GMOS sequence that sequences the wavelength setting is the same as for the science observation such that arcs are taken at both wavelengths. The observation contain 2 wavelength settings in order to cover the gap between the CCDs and get full wavelength coverage.

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This is an acquisition observation for a longslit standard observation. It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
The class has been set to 'Acquisition Calibration'.
There is no target component as an appropriate target will be supplied by the Gemini observing staff when it is convenient to observe the spectrophotometric baseline standards.
The first step is an imaging exposure with the CCD binned 1x1 with ROI Central Stamp (300x300 pixels FOV).
The second step is a 20sec image through the slit (offset P=10 arcsec, which is reverted in the 3rd step) that is used to measure the slit center with the CCD binned 1x1 and the ROI set to Central Stamp.
The third step is an image through the slit that is used to confirm the offsets have well centered the science target within the slit , again the CCD is binned 1x1 with ROI Central Stamp (300x300 pixels FOV).
The fourth step is a copy of the third step and is used only if necessary to further adjust the centering of the star in the slit.
The user may need to adjust the exposure times of the first and second steps as appropriate for their science target. Use the ITC to find the exposure time needed. A S/N>=10 is recommended for acquisition observations. The exposure time of the slit image (second step) should be left as defined at 20 seconds.

param.name: title
param.value: Longslit: Baseline Standard: observation with GCALflats

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This example is a longslit standard observation with GCAL flats mixed in.
The class of the observes is 'Nighttime Partner Calibration'.
It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
The filter, grating, central wavelength, ccd binning, and FPU should match the configurations used in the science observation. There is no need to dither a spectrophotometric standard observation either spectrally or spatially.
For programs with multiple wavelength settings used to span the gaps between the CCDs, only one of these wavlength settings will be taken for the spectrophotometric standard. Baseline relative flux calibration is a smooth function which can be interpolated across the gaps in the detector. Programs which need spectrophotometric standard or telluric standard calibration beyond that provided by this minimal baseline standard definition will need to define a program calibration standard star whose time will be charged against the alotted time.
The target component has been removed as Gemini observing staff will select an appropriate standard star that is accessible when conditions are convenient for observing baseline standards.

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
- This is a longslit CuAr arc, to be taken as the baseline calibration during the day (class=Daytime Calibration).
- The guide star has been removed from the target component, since the telescope will be stationary at zenith for this observation.
- The Translation Stage has been set to "Follow in Z Only" since the telescope is stationary and the Telescope Control System may not be up when this observation is taken.
- The readout is "fast" in order to save time.
- Because this CuAr is for the standard star observation the ROI is set to central spectrum.
- It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This example shows a Longslit twilight flat, to be taken as the baseline calibration (class=Daytime Calibration).
It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
The guide star has been removed from the target component, since twilight flats are taken at blank fields and without guiding. There is no reason to enter the actual coordinates of the blank field.
For programs with multiple wavelength settings used to span the gaps between the CCDs, only one of these wavelength settings will have a twilight flat taken.
The exposure time is set to 30sec in the GMOS sequence. This makes it easy for the observer to adjust it as needed for the brightness of the sky.
The exposure is taken on the sky so the Translation stage should be 'Follow in X, Y, and Z (focus)'.

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This is the longslit acquisition template for science observation of a point source centered in the middle of CCD2. It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
The class has been set to 'Acquisition'.
The first step is an imaging exposure with the CCD binned 2x2 (CCD2)
The second step is a 20s image through the slit that is used to measure the slit center (offset P=10 arcsec, which is reverted in the 3rd step) with the CCD binned 1x1 and the ROI set to Central Stamp (300x300 pixels FOV).
The third step is an image through the slit that is used to confirm the offsets have well centered the science target within the slit , again the CCD is binned 1x1 with ROI Central Stamp (300x300 pixel FOV)
The user will need to adjust the exposure time to be appropriate for a given target. Use the ITC to find the exposure time needed. A S/N>=10 is recommended for acquisition observations. The exposure time of the slit image (second step) should be left as defined at 20 seconds.

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
Take first 2 images (wait for astigmatism to be < ~0.2 especially if using the image to judge IQ). cl> gacq 1
Take an image through slit to confirm/tweak centering. **MUST TAKE THIS IMAGE.** cl> gacq 3 (when the gacq asks you if you want to use the previously measured slit center say yes)
Need another? cl> gacq 4 (when the gacq asks you if you want to use the previously measured slit center say yes)
---
Details: 1 = source image (CCD2) 2 = 20s image through slit used for measuring the slit center (STAMP) should be found automatically by gacq the first time, and afterward the recorded slit center should be used. can specify to use this slitimage specifically in the second and third iterations manually if you get into trouble by specifying slitimage=2 on the gacq command line (eg. gacq 3 slitimage=2) 3 = source through slit (STAMP) 4 = source through slit (STAMP)

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This is a N&S longslit science observation of a faint target with GCAL flats mixed in.
Nod offset is +-5arcsec, use the standard shuffling (1536 rows and a binning of X=2, Y=1. It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
The observation contain 1 science exposure and 1 GCALflat at each of 3 wavelength settings, 770nm, 780nm and 790nm. Three wavelength settings are used to cover the gap between the CCDs and get full wavelength coverage. An DtaX offset (0,-2,2) is used in each wavelength setting.
The exposures are the follow: science at 780nm, DtaX=0 GCALflat at 780nm, DtaX=0 GCALflat at 780nm. DtaX=-2 science at 780nm DtaX=-2 science at 780nm, DtaX=2 GCALflat at 780nm, DtaX=2 GCALflat at 790nm. DtaX=0 science at 790nm DtaX=0 science at 790nm, DtaX=-2 GCALflat at 790nm, DtaX=-2 science at 790nm, DtaX=2 GCALflat at 790nm, DtaX=2 science at 770nm, DtaX=0 GCALflat at 770nm, DtaX=0 GCALflat at 770nm. DtaX=-2 science at 770nm DtaX=-2 science at 770nm, DtaX=2 GCALflat at 770nm, DtaX=2
The DTAX offset dither sequence is recommended to help reduce the effect of charge traps in the data; see the N&S web pages. Here by using four GMOS-N Sequences to change central wavelength and dither the DTAX we save on overhead with an efficient science-flat-flat-science-science-flat-flat-science arrangement, minimizing the number of calibration congfiguration movements required.

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
- This is a N&S longslit CuAr arc, to be taken as the baseline calibration during the day (class=Daytime Calibration).
- The guide star has been removed from the target component, since the telescope will be stationary at zenith for this observation.
- The Translation Stage has been set to "Follow in Z Only" since the telescope is stationary and the Telescope Control System may not be up when this observation is taken.
- The readout is "fast" in order to save time.
- The instrument is configured to use 2x2 binning, a central wavelengths of 750nm and 755nm and the OG515 blocking filter, to avoid 2nd order contamination in the spectrum.
- It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
- The GMOS sequence that sequences the wavelength setting is the same as for the science observation such that arcs are taken at the same wavelengths. The different wavelength settings are used to cover the gap between the CCDs and get full wavelength coverage.

param.name: title
param.value: N&S Longslit Baseline Standard: acquisition observation

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This is an acquisition observation for a longslit standard observation. It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
The class has been set to 'Acquisition Calibration'.
There is no target component as an appropriate target will be supplied by the Gemini observing staff when it is convenient to observe the spectrophotometric baseline standards.
The first step is an imaging exposure with the CCD binned 1x1 with ROI Central Stamp (300x300 pixels FOV).
The second step is a 20sec image through the slit (offset P=10 arcsec, which is reverted in the 3rd step) that is used to measure the slit center with the CCD binned 1x1 and the ROI set to Central Stamp.
The third step is an image through the slit that is used to confirm the offsets have well centered the science target within the slit , again the CCD is binned 1x1 with ROI Central Stamp (300x300 pixels FOV).
The fourth step is a copy of the third step and is used only if necessary to further adjust the centering of the star in the slit.
The user may need to adjust the exposure times of the first and second steps as appropriate for their science target. Use the ITC to find the exposure time needed. A S/N>=10 is recommended for acquisition observations. The exposure time of the slit image (second step) should be left as defined at 20 seconds.
- the user should set the filter in order to choose the one with an effective wavelength closest to the central wavelength used for the spectroscopy

param.name: title
param.value: N&S Longslit Baseline Standard: observation with GCALflats

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This is a longslit standard observation with GCAL flats mixed in.
The class of the observes is 'Nighttime Partner Calibration'.
It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
The observation uses Central Spectrum (central 1/3 of each of the 3 CCDs in y-direction)
The PI must edit the central wavelength and ccd binning match the configurations used in the science observation. There is no need to dither a spectrophotometric standard observation either spectrally or spatially.
For programs with multiple wavelength settings used to span the gaps between the CCDs, only one of these wavlength settings will be taken for the spectrophotometric standard. Baseline relative flux calibration is a smooth function which can be interpolated across the gaps in the detector. Programs which need spectrophotometric standard or telluric standard calibration beyond that provided by this minimal baseline standard definition will need to define a program calibration standard star whose time will be charged against the alotted time.
The target component has been removed as Gemini observing staff will select an appropriate standard star that is accessible when conditions are convenient for observing baseline standards.

param.name: title
param.value: N&S Longslit Baseline Standard CuAr arc

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
- This is a longslit CuAr arc, to be taken as the baseline calibration during the day (class=Daytime Calibration) for flux standard
- The guide star has been removed from the target component, since the telescope will be stationary at zenith for this observation.
- The Translation Stage has been set to "Follow in Z Only" since the telescope is stationary and the Telescope Control System may not be up when this observation is taken.
- The readout is "fast" in order to save time.
- Because this CuAr is for the standard star observation the ROI is set to central spectrum. (central 1/3 of each of the 3 CCDs in y-direction)
- The instrument is configured to use 2x2 binning, a central wavelengths of 750nm and the OG515 blocking filter, to avoid 2nd order contamination in the spectrum.
- It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This is a Longslit twilight flat, to be taken as the baseline calibration (class=Daytime Calibration).
The instrument is configured to use 2x2 binning, a central wavelength of 750nm.
It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
The guide star has been removed from the target component, since twilight flats are taken at blank fields and without guiding. There is no reason to enter the actual coordinates of the blank field.
For programs with multiple wavelength settings used to span the gaps between the CCDs, only one of these wavelength settings will have a twilight flat taken.
The exposure time is set to 30sec in the GMOS sequence. This makes it easy for the observer to adjust it as needed for the brightness of the sky.
The exposure is taken on the sky so the Translation stage should be 'Follow in X, Y, and Z (focus)'.

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This is a Longslit Nod&Shuffle Baseline Dark to be taken as the baseline calibration (class=Daytime Calibration). This N&S dark would be useful for removing charge traps from Longslit data.
For Nod&Shuffle darks the following parameters must match the science observation exactly in order to get a good correction:
The instrument is configured as following: r-filter (to avoid an OTwarning), disperser mirror, no FPU. The Nod & Shuffle parameters MUST MATCH the science configuration. There are four parameters that define a Nod & Shuffle dark:
Exposure time A=60sec. Note that the 60sec exposure time in A (in this example) MUST BE SET in the DARK component exposure time. The exposure time is NOT TAKEN from the GMOS-S component.
Offset (shuffle distance) = 1536 rows for N&S LONGSLIT darks.
Number of N&S cycles (same as the science exposure) = 15 in this example. Therefore, The total open shutter time is 1800sec per dark exposure in this example. Note that the number of N&S cycles IS taken from the static GMOS-S component. For example, setting the Dark to have an Observe 15x will take 15 N&S darks, each having 15 N&S cycles.
Detector Binning = 2x2 in this example
The guide star has been removed from the target component since the telescope will be stationary at zenith for this observation.
The Translation Stage has been set to "Do not follow" since the telescope is stationary and the Telescope Control System may not be up when this observation is taken.
Nod & Shuffle Darks will be taken on a best-effort basis when the telescope is closed for bad weather.
Number of N&S observations is 15

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This example shows an observing sequence for MOS pre-imaging.
The pre-imaging is done in the r' filter and using a dither sequence.
It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
The CCD is read out binned 2x2.
Because this imaging observation will be used to design a MOS mask the "MOS pre-imaging" box on the GMOS-S static component is checked. By checking this box MOS pre-imaging observations are automatically identified for early scheduling and the data are reduced and distributed to the PI in an effort to reduce the turn-around time before the MOS mask can be submitted.

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This is an acquisition observation for a MOS science observation where the first image is taken with the mask in the beam. This is the normal MOS acquisition mode for masks designed from pre-imaging observations.
Custom ROIs ----------- This observation is set up to use a CUSTOM ROI where only the pixels imaging the acquisition box are read out. No other pixels are saved. The Custom ROI cannot be defined until after the mask has been designed and submitted. The Custom ROI field (for up to 4 acquisiton objects currently) will be filled in by Gemini Staff. The Custom ROI is only used for the images when the MOS mask is in the beam. The field image is read out using Full Frame. -----------
If either of the MOS mask was designed from an object catalog derived from imaging taken with other telescopes then the "MOS: Acq starting with the mask out of the beam" template must be used instead..
It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
The target is acquired using the r-filter, (user can set it to that closest to the wavelength setting used for the spectroscopy)
The observation consists of 4 exposures through the mask. During acquisition, the observer will step through the exposures adjusting the telescope offsets to align the acquisition objects in the acquisition holes in the mask. Not all 4 exposures may be used in this process.
If the acquisition objects are unusually faint, the user will have to adjust the exposure time as needed.
The maskname used in this template will have to be edited in order to match the MOS mask name used by the science program. The mask name has the following format:
GNYYYY(A/B)(Q/C/DD/SV)PPP-MM
Where YYYY is the year, (A/B) stands for either semester A or B, (Q/C/DD/SV) stands for either Queue, Classical, Director's Discretionary or Science Verification programs, PPP is the program number, and MM is the mask number (a MOS PI may design several masks for use, with a technical limit of 99 masks).

param.name: title
param.value: MOS: Acq starting with mask out of the beam

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This is an acquisition observation for a MOS science observation where the first image is taken with the mask out of the beam. This is the recommended MOS acquisition mode if the MOS mask was designed from an object catalog derived from imaging taken with other telescopes
Any MOS acquisition for MOS masks which were designed from pre-imaging obtained in the current semester should use the default MOS: acq which starts with the MOS mask already in the beam.
It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
The target is acquired using the r-filter (user can set it to that closest to the wavelength setting used for the spectroscopy)
The second sequence consists of 4 exposures through the mask. During acquisition, the observer will step through the exposures adjusting the telescope offsets to align the acquisition objects in the acquisition holes in the mask. Not all 4 exposures may be used in this process.
If the acquisition objects are unusually faint, the user will have to adjust the exposure time as needed.
The maskname used in this template will have to be edited in order to match the MOS mask name used by the science program. The mask name has the following format:
GSYYYY(A/B)(Q/C/DD/SV)PPP-MM
Where YYYY is the year, (A/B) stands for either semester A or B, (Q/C/DD/SV) stands for either Queue, Classical, Director's Discretionary or Science Verification programs, PPP is the program number, and MM is the mask number (a MOS PI may design several masks for use, with a technical limit of 99 masks).

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
The first acquistiion image in this observation is taken with the mask out of the beam. Because the gacq cannot tell the difference between MOS and longslit acq if thereis no mask in the beam you must use a modified gacq command for the first image taken:
gacq *filenumber* mosmask=#
eg if the image is S20060927S0034.fits and the mosmask ID is GS2008AQ026-04 then the command you would type would be:
gacq 34 mosmask=4
This only applies when the mask is out of the beam. For acquisition images with the mask in the beam use the regular
gacq *filenumber*
- Kathy

param.name: title
param.value: GMOS-S: Defining the Custom Mask MDF

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This is a MOS science observation with GCAL flats mixed in. The mask is for the program GSYYYYSQXXX-NN It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
The observation contain 1 science exposure and 1 GCALflat at each of 3 wavelength settings. The different wavelength settings are used to cover the gap between the CCDs and get full wavelength coverage. Instead of using one GMOS sequence, 3 sequences are used. This makes it possible to order the exposures as follows: science at 520nm GCALflat at 520nm GCALflat at 540nm science at 540nm
If only one GMOS sequence had been used the order would have been science 520nm GCALflat 520nm science 540nm GCALflat 540nm This would take longer because the science fold mirror used for taking the flats has to move more often.
The user should specify the slit width used in the mask (1.00 arcsec is set by default). This is used to compute the exposure time for GCAL flats.
The maskname used in this template will have to be edited in order to match the MOS mask name used by the science program. The mask name has the following format:
GSYYYY(A/B)(Q/C/DD/SV)PPP-MM
Where YYYY is the year, (A/B) stands for either semester A or B, (Q/C/DD/SV) stands for either Queue, Classical, Director's Discretionary or Science Verification programs, PPP is the program number, and MM is the mask number (a MOS PI may design several masks for use, with a technical limit of 99 masks).

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
- This is a MOS CuAr arc, to be taken as the baseline calibration during the day (class=Daytime Calibration).
- The guide star has been removed from the target component, since the telescope will be stationary at zenith for this observation.
- The Translation Stage has been set to "Follow in Z Only" since the telescope is stationary and the Telescope Control System may not be up when this observation is taken.
- The ROI is Full frame and the readout is "fast" in order to save time.
-The user should specify the slit width used in the mask (1.00 arcsec is set by default). This is used to compute the exposure time for GCAL flats.
- The instrument is configured to use a central wavelength of 520nm and 525nm. The mask is GSYYYYSQXXX-NN Mask slit width is to be set by user. It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
- The GMOS sequence that sequences the wavelength setting is the same as for the science observation such that arcs are taken at both wavelengths. The observation contain 2 wavelength settings, 520nm and 525nm. Two wavelength settings are used to cover the gap between the CCDs and get full wavelength coverage.

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This is a MOS mask image, to be taken as the baseline calibration during the day (class=Daytime Calibration).
The mask is GSYYYYSQXXX-NN It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
The guide star has been removed from the target component, since the telescope will be stationary at zenith for this observation.
The DTA has been set to "Do not follow" since the telescope is stationary and the Telescope Control System may not be up when this observation is taken.
The readout is "fast" in order to save time.
All mask images are taken with the CCD unbinned and using the r-filter, independent of the instrument configuration for the science observations.
This observation is set up to take two images. The first uses Full Frame and is used to verify the mask has been cut appropriately. The second uses a CUSTOM ROI where only the pixels imaging the acquisition box are read out. No other pixels are saved. The Custom ROI cannot be defined until after the mask has been designed and submitted. The Custom ROI field (for up to 4 acquisiton objects currently) will be filled in by Gemini Staff. The second image is used to verify that the acquisition boxes can be read out appropriately using Custom ROIs. If the mask has more than 4 acquistion boxes or if the boxes result in overlapping detector rows the acquisition image will be reverted to use Full Frame by Gemini Staff.

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This is a MOS twilight flat, to be taken as the baseline calibration (class=Daytime Calibration). The instrument is configured to use a central wavelength of 520nm. The mask is GSYYYYSQXXX-NN. It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port Mask slit width is to be set by user
The guide star has been removed from the target component, since twilight flats are taken at blank fields and without guiding. There is no reason to enter the actual coordinates of the blank field.
For programs with multiple wavelength settings used to span the gaps between the CCDs, only one of these wavelength settings will have a twilight flat taken.
The exposure time is set to 30sec in the GMOS sequence. This makes it easy for the observer to adjust it as needed for the brightness of the sky.
The exposure is taken on the sky so the Translation stage should be 'Follow in X, Y, and Z (focus)'.

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This is an acquisition observation for a longslit standard observation. It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port. Slit width is to be set by user
The class has been set to 'Acquisition Calibration'.
There is no target component as an appropriate target will be supplied by the Gemini observing staff when it is convenient to observe the spectrophotometric baseline standards.
The target is acquired using the g-filter, (user can set it to that closest to the wavelength setting used for the spectroscopy) The FPU, binning and exposure time are sequenced. The first step is an imaging exposure with the CCD binned 1x1 with ROI Central Stamp (300x300 pixels FOV). The second step is a 20sec image through the slit that is used to measure the slit center with the CCD binned 1x1 and the ROI set to Central Stamp. The third step is an image through the slit that is used to confirm the offsets have well centered the science target within the slit , again the CCD is binned 1x1 with ROI Central Stamp (300x300 pixels FOV).
The user may need to adjust the exposure times of the first and second steps as appropriate for their science target. Use the ITC to find the exposure time needed. A S/N>=10 is recommended for acquisition observations. The exposure time of the slit image (second step) should be left as defined at 10 seconds.

param.name: title
param.value: MOS: Baseline Standard: observation with GCALflats

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
- The is a longslit standard observation with GCAL flats mixed in.
- The class of the observes is 'Nighttime Partner Calibration'.
- Slit width is to be set by user to match the science observations. It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
-There is no target component as an appropriate target will be supplied by the Gemini observing staff when it is convenient to observe the spectrophotometric baseline standards.
- The observation uses Central Spectrum (central 1/3 of each of the 3 CCDs in y-direction)
- Three wavelengths are used to bracked the wavelengths that will be detected by the MOS observations. The middle setting is the same as one of the MOS spectral dithers.
- The observation contain 1 science exposure and 1 GCALflat at each of 3 wavelength settings, 460nm, 520nm and 580nm. Three wavelengths are used to bracked the wavelengths that will be detected by the MOS observations. The middle setting is the same as one of the MOS spectral dithers.
Instead of using one GMOS sequence, 3 sequences are used. This makes it possible to order the exposures as follows: science at 460nm GCALflat at 460nm GCALflat at 520nm science at 520nm science at 580nm GCALflat at 580nm

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
- This is a longslit CuAr arc, to be taken as the baseline calibration during the day (class=Daytime Calibration) for flux standard
- The guide star has been removed from the target component, since the telescope will be stationary at zenith for this observation.
- The Translation Stage has been set to "Follow in Z Only" since the telescope is stationary and the Telescope Control System may not be up when this observation is taken.
- The readout is "fast" in order to save time.
- Baseline standard and Baseline CuAr arc are observed with the same grating, filter, slit width, and binning configuration used for the science observation.
- The observations use a ROI Central Spectrum (central 1/3 of each of the 3 CCDs in y-direction). Three central wavelengths are used to bracked the wavelengths that will be detected by the MOS observations. The middle setting is the same as one of the MOS spectral dithers.
- The instrument is configured to use a central wavelength of 460, 520nm and 580nm. - The slit width is to be set by the user
It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This is an acquisition observation for a MOS science observation where the first image is taken with the mask in the beam. This is the normal MOS acquisition mode for masks designed from pre-imaging observations.
Custom ROIs ----------- This observation is set up to use a CUSTOM ROI where only the pixels imaging the acquisition box are read out. No other pixels are saved. The Custom ROI cannot be defined until after the mask has been designed and submitted. The Custom ROI field (for up to 4 acquisiton objects currently) will be filled in by Gemini Staff. The Custom ROI is only used for the images when the MOS mask is in the beam. The field image is read out using Full Frame. -----------
If either of the MOS mask was designed from an object catalog derived from imaging taken with other telescopes then the "MOS: Acq starting with the mask out of the beam" template must be used instead..
It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
The target is acquired using the r-filter, (user can set it to that closest to the wavelength setting used for the spectroscopy)
The observation consists of 4 exposures through the mask. During acquisition, the observer will step through the exposures adjusting the telescope offsets to align the acquisition objects in the acquisition holes in the mask. Not all 4 exposures may be used in this process.
If the acquisition objects are unusually faint, the user will have to adjust the exposure time as needed.
The maskname used in this template will have to be edited in order to match the MOS mask name used by the science program. The mask name has the following format:
GNYYYY(A/B)(Q/C/DD/SV)PPP-MM
Where YYYY is the year, (A/B) stands for either semester A or B, (Q/C/DD/SV) stands for either Queue, Classical, Director's Discretionary or Science Verification programs, PPP is the program number, and MM is the mask number (a MOS PI may design several masks for use, with a technical limit of 99 masks).

param.name: title
param.value: MOS N&S: Acq starting with mask out of the beam

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This is an acquisition observation for a MOS science observation where the first image is taken with the mask out of the beam. This is the recommended MOS acquisition mode if the MOS mask was designed from an object catalog derived from imaging taken with other telescopes
Any MOS acquisition for MOS masks which were designed from pre-imaging obtained in the current semester should use the default MOS: acq which starts with the MOS mask already in the beam.
It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
The target is acquired using the r-filter (user can set it to that closest to the wavelength setting used for the spectroscopy)
The second sequence consists of 4 exposures through the mask. During acquisition, the observer will step through the exposures adjusting the telescope offsets to align the acquisition objects in the acquisition holes in the mask. Not all 4 exposures may be used in this process.
If the acquisition objects are unusually faint, the user will have to adjust the exposure time as needed.
The maskname used in this template will have to be edited in order to match the MOS mask name used by the science program. The mask name has the following format:
GSYYYY(A/B)(Q/C/DD/SV)PPP-MM
Where YYYY is the year, (A/B) stands for either semester A or B, (Q/C/DD/SV) stands for either Queue, Classical, Director's Discretionary or Science Verification programs, PPP is the program number, and MM is the mask number (a MOS PI may design several masks for use, with a technical limit of 99 masks).

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
The first acquistiion image in this observation is taken with the mask out of the beam. Because the gacq cannot tell the difference between MOS and longslit acq if thereis no mask in the beam you must use a modified gacq command for the first image taken:
gacq *filenumber* mosmask=#
eg if the image is N20060927S0034.fits and the mosmask ID is GN2008AQ026-04 then the command you would type would be:
gacq 34 mosmask=4
This only applies when the mask is out of the beam. For acquisition images with the mask in the beam use the regular
gacq *filenumber*
- Kathy

param.name: title
param.value: GMOS-S: Defining the Custom Mask MDF

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This is a MOS Nod&Shuffle science observation with GCAL flats mixed in.
The instrument is configured to use a central wavelength of 780nm. A Custom MOS mask with the name GSYYYYSQXXX-NN is used. The mask slit width is to be set by the user The mask used in this example does not exist, but the N&S static component is set to use an offset (shuffle distance) of 32 detector rows, corresponding to a distance of 2.34". This would be appropriate for a MOS mask designed to use micro-shuffling with a slit length of 2.34". This sequence uses also electronic offsets (e-offsets)
Note that this shuffle offset of 2.34 arc-seconds is NOT the same as the nod (sky offset) used for dithering (1.5 arc-seconds in this example). The shuffle offset is set by the MOS slit length, and is defined in the Nod-and-Shuffle tab. The NOD is designed to offset the objects but keep them in the slit at the two positions, so these offsets are defined with respect to the slit center and should be smaller than the half the defined slit length. The NODs are only in the q direction, along the slit, and not in the p direction which is across the slit.
The sequence dithers the DTAX in order to minimize the effect of "charge trap" features which appear in Nod & Shuffled data. The sequence also dithers the grating spectrally by by 10 nm above and below the central wavelength in order to fill in the information missing due to the gaps between the detectors.
It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
Because the total extent of the N&S nod is small (<2arcsec) the user can select electronic offsetting (e-offsets). This is recommended since it will significantly reduce the N&S overhead. This sequence uses e-offsets.
The observation contains nested GMOS-S iterators in order to sequence both the DTAX and the central wavelength. By using nested GMOS-S Sequences to dither the DTAX and central wavelength we save on overhead with an efficient flat-science-science-flat-flat-science arrangement, minimizing the numberof calibration congfiguration movements required.
Each science exposure consists of 15 N&S cycles. The nods are along the slits, keeping the science targets in the slits at all times. The total on-target open shutter time is 1800sec per science exposure in this example, 4.5hour total for the full observation.
The other required observations for a MOS N&S program are similar to those for non N&S MOS program. Only the actual science observation is taken with Nod&Shuffle.
The other required observations for a N&S MOS program include:
MOS: Acq MOS: N&S Science
and the Baseline Calibrations include:
MOS: N&S Dark MOS: Mask Image (one for each MOS mask) MOS: CuAr (one for each MOS mask) MOS: Acq (Standard) MOS: Standard w/ flats MOS: CuAr (Standard) MOS: Twilight flat (optional, one for each MOS mask)
Normally for MOS observations the MOS: Acq, MOS: N&S Science, MOS: Mask Image, MOS: CuAr and MOS: Twilight are organized into a separate folder for each MOS mask, while the MOS: N&S Dark, MOS: Acq (Standard), MOS: Standard w/ flats, and MOS: CuAr (Standard) are organized together in a separate Baseline Calibrations folder.
SLITWIDTH: The user should specify the slit width used in the mask (1.00 arcsec is set by default). This is used to compute the exposure time for GCAL flats.
MASKNAME: The maskname used in this template will have to be edited in order to match the MOS mask name used by the science program. The mask name has the following format:
GNYYYY(A/B)(Q/C/DD/SV)PPP-MM
Where YYYY is the year, (A/B) stands for either semester A or B, (Q/C/DD/SV) stands for either Queue, Classical, Director's Discretionary or Science Verification programs, PPP is the program number, and MM is the mask number (a MOS PI may design several masks for use, with a technical limit of 99 masks).

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
The darks are useful for removing charge traps from Nod & Shuffle spectral data.
This example shows a MOS Nod&Shuffle Baseline Dark to be taken as the baseline calibration (class=Daytime Calibration).
The instrument is configured as following: r-filter (to avoid an OTwarning), disperser mirror, no FPU. The Nod & Shuffle parameters MUST MATCH the science configuration. There are four parameters that define a Nod & Shuffle dark:
Exposure time A=60sec. Note that the 60sec exposure time in A (in this example) MUST BE SET in the DARK component exposure time. The exposure time is NOT TAKEN from the GMOS-S component.
Offset (shuffle distance) = 32 rows in this example. This is in unit of "unbinned" pixels.
Number of N&S cycles (same as the science exposure) = 15 in this example. Therefore, The total open shutter time is 1800sec per dark exposure in this example. Note that the number of N&S cycles IS taken from the static GMOS-S component. For example, setting the Dark to have an Observe 15x will take 15 N&S darks, each having 15 N&S cycles.
Detector Binning = 2x2 in this example
The guide star has been removed from the target component since the telescope will be stationary at zenith for this observation.
The Translation Stage has been set to "Do not follow" since the telescope is stationary and the Telescope Control System may not be up when this observation is taken.
Nod & Shuffle Darks will be taken on a best-effort basis when the telescope is closed for bad weather.

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
- This is a MOS CuAr arc, to be taken as the baseline calibration during the day (class=Daytime Calibration).
- The guide star has been removed from the target component, since the telescope will be stationary at zenith for this observation.
- The Translation Stage has been set to "Follow in Z Only" since the telescope is stationary and the Telescope Control System may not be up when this observation is taken.
- The ROI is Full frame and the readout is "fast" in order to save time.
- The instrument is configured to use a central wavelength of 520nm and 525nm. The mask is GSYYYYSQXXX-NN Mask slit width is to be set by user. It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
-SLITWIDTH: The user should specify the slit width used in the mask (1.00 arcsec is set by default). This is used to compute the exposure time for GCAL flats.
- The GMOS sequence that sequences the wavelength setting is the same as for the science observation such that arcs are taken at both wavelengths. The observation contain 2 wavelength settings, 520nm and 525nm. Two wavelength settings are used to cover the gap between the CCDs and get full wavelength coverage.

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This is a MOS twilight flat, to be taken as the baseline calibration (class=Daytime Calibration). The instrument is configured to use a central wavelength of 520nm. The mask is GSYYYYSQXXX-NN It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port Mask slit width is to be set by user
The guide star has been removed from the target component, since twilight flats are taken at blank fields and without guiding. There is no reason to enter the actual coordinates of the blank field.
For programs with multiple wavelength settings used to span the gaps between the CCDs, only one of these wavelength settings will have a twilight flat taken.
The exposure time is set to 30sec in the GMOS sequence. This makes it easy for the observer to adjust it as needed for the brightness of the sky.
The exposure is taken on the sky so the Translation stage should be 'Follow in X, Y, and Z (focus)'.

param.name: title
param.value: MOS N&S: Baseline Standard: acquisition observation

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This is an acquisition observation for a longslit standard observation. It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port. Slit width is to be set by user
The class has been set to 'Acquisition Calibration'.
There is no target component as an appropriate target will be supplied by the Gemini observing staff when it is convenient to observe the spectrophotometric baseline standards.
The target is acquired using the g-filter (user can set it to that closest to the wavelength setting used for the spectroscopy) The FPU, binning and exposure time are sequenced. The first step is an imaging exposure with the CCD binned 1x1 with ROI Central Stamp (300x300 pixels FOV). The second step is a 10sec image through the slit that is used to measure the slit center with the CCD binned 1x1 and the ROI set to Central Stamp. The third step is an image through the slit that is used to confirm the offsets have well centered the science target within the slit , again the CCD is binned 1x1 with ROI Central Stamp (300x300 pixels FOV).
The user may need to adjust the exposure times of the first and second steps as appropriate for their science target. Use the ITC to find the exposure time needed. A S/N>=10 is recommended for acquisition observations. The exposure time of the slit image (second step) should be left as defined at 10 seconds.

param.name: title
param.value: MOS N&S: Baseline Standard: observation with GCALflats

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
- The is a longslit standard observation with GCAL flats mixed in.
- The class of the observes is 'Nighttime Partner Calibration'.
- Slit width is to be set by user to match the science observations. It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
-There is no target component as an appropriate target will be supplied by the Gemini observing staff when it is convenient to observe the spectrophotometric baseline standards.
- The observation uses Central Spectrum (central 1/3 of each of the 3 CCDs in y-direction)
- Three wavelengths are used to bracked the wavelengths that will be detected by the MOS observations. The middle setting is the same as one of the MOS spectral dithers.
- The observation contain 1 science exposure and 1 GCALflat at each of 3 wavelength settings, 460nm, 520nm and 580nm. Three wavelengths are used to bracked the wavelengths that will be detected by the MOS observations. The middle setting is the same as one of the MOS spectral dithers.
Instead of using one GMOS sequence, 3 sequences are used. This makes it possible to order the exposures as follows: science at 460nm GCALflat at 460nm GCALflat at 520nm science at 520nm science at 580nm GCALflat at 580nm

param.name: title
param.value: MOS N&S: Baseline Standard CuAr arc

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
- This is a longslit CuAr arc, to be taken as the baseline calibration during the day (class=Daytime Calibration) for flux standard
- The guide star has been removed from the target component, since the telescope will be stationary at zenith for this observation.
- The Translation Stage has been set to "Follow in Z Only" since the telescope is stationary and the Telescope Control System may not be up when this observation is taken.
- The readout is "fast" in order to save time.
- Baseline standard and Baseline CuAr arc are observed with the same grating, filter, slit width, and binning configuration used for the science observation.
- The observations use a ROI Central Spectrum (central 1/3 of each of the 3 CCDs in y-direction). Three central wavelengths are used to bracked the wavelengths that will be detected by the MOS observations. The middle setting is the same as one of the MOS spectral dithers.
- The instrument is configured to use a central wavelength of 460, 520nm and 580nm. Slit width is to be set by user. It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This is an acquisition observation for an IFU-1 science observation. It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
The class has been set to 'Acquisition'.
The FPU, ROI, binning and exposure time are sequenced. Step1: imaging exposure with the CCD binned 2x2 Step2,3...: images through the IFU, full frame readout with the CCD binned 1x1
The user will need to adjust the exposure time to be appropriate for a given target. Use the ITC to find the exposure time needed. A S/N>=10 is recommended for acquisition observations.
For targets fainter than R~18mag, imaging through the IFU will take too long. Instead a blind offset acquisition should be used. For more information on blind offsetting, please see http://www.gemini.edu/sciops/telescopes-and-sites/acquisition-hardware-and-techniques/acquisition-techniques. For help setting up the acquistion, see the Description note for the "Longslit Acquisition (Blind Offset)" within the Templates: Spectroscopy Acquisition Observations folder. If it is not possible to find a nearby reference star with well known coordinates for blind offsetting, make the 2nd step be another imaging exposure, such that the position of the target on the CCD in imaging mode can be checked after the initial telescope offset has been determined and applied. The blind offset method is preferred because the user can directly measure from the acquisition image where the science target will approximately fall in the IFU field of view.

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This is an IFU observation followed by a GCAL flat field.
It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
Two offset positions are used to fill in dead fibers.
For targets fainter than R~18mag, imaging through the IFU will take too long. Instead a blind offset acquisition should be used. For more information on blind offsetting, please see http://www.gemini.edu/sciops/telescopes-and-sites/acquisition-hardware-and-techniques/acquisition-techniques. For help setting up the acquistion, see the Description note for the "Longslit Acquisition (Blind Offset)" within the Templates: Spectroscopy Acquisition Observations folder. If it is not possible to find a nearby reference star with well known coordinates for blind offsetting, make the 2nd step be another imaging exposure, such that the position of the target on the CCD in imaging mode can be checked after the initial telescope offset has been determined and applied. The blind offset method is preferred because the user can directly measure from the acquisition image where the science target will approximately fall in the IFU field of view.

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This example shows an IFU-2 CuAr arc, to be taken as the baseline calibration during the day (class=Daytime Calibration).
The instrument is configured to use the central wavelength set to 650nm.
The guide star has been removed from the target component, since the telescope will be stationary at zenith for this observation.
The DTA has been set to "Follow in Z Only" since the telescope is stationary and the Telescope Control System may not be up when this observation is taken.
The readout is "fast" in order to save time.

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This is an IFU twilight flat, to be taken as the baseline calibration (class=Daytime Calibration).
The guide star has been removed from the target component, since twilight flats are taken at blank fields and without guiding. There is no reason to enter the actual coordinates of the blank field.
For programs with multiple wavelength settings used to span the gaps between the CCDs, only one of these wavelength settings will have a twilight flat taken.
The exposure time is set to 30sec in the GMOS sequence. This makes it easy for the observer to adjust it as needed for the brightness of the sky.
The exposure is taken on the sky so the Translation stage should be 'Follow in X, Y, and Z (focus)'.

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
- This example shows an IFU CuAr arc, to be taken as the baseline calibration during the day (class=Daytime Calibration) for Baseline Standard.
- The guide star has been removed from the target component, since the telescope will be stationary at zenith for this observation.
- The Translation Stage has been set to "Follow in Z Only" since the telescope is stationary and the Telescope Control System may not be up when this observation is taken.
- The readout is "fast" in order to save time.
- The instrument is configured to use 1x1 binning. It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This example shows an acquisition observation for an IFU Baseline standard observation. It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
The class has been set to 'Acquisition Calibration'.
There is no target component as an appropriate target will be supplied by the Gemini observing staff when it is convenient to observe the spectrophotometric baseline standards.
The FPU, ROI, binning and exposure time are sequenced. Step1: imaging exposure with the CCD binned 2x2 Step2,3...: images through the IFU, full frame readout with the CCD binned 1x1
The user may need to adjust the exposure times of the first and second steps as appropriate for their science target. Use the ITC to find the exposure time needed. A S/N>=10 is recommended for acquisition observations. The exposure time of the slit image (second step) should be left as defined at 10 seconds.

param.name: title
param.value: IFU: Baseline Standard: observation with GCALflats

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This example shows an IFU standard observation with GCAL flats mixed in.
The class of the observes is 'Nghttime Partner Calibration'.
It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
The observation contain 1 science exposure and 1 GCALflat at each of 2 wavelength settings, 650nm and 655nm. Two wavelength settings is used to cover the gap between the CCDs and get full wavelength coverage. Instead of using one GMOS sequence, 2 sequences are used. This makes it possible to order the exposures as follows: science at 650nm GCALflat at 650nm GCALflat at 655nm science at 655nm

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This example shows an acquisition observation for an IFU N&S science observation. It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
The class has been set to 'Acquisition'.
The FPU, ROI, binning and exposure time are sequenced. Step1: imaging exposure with the CCD binned 2x2 Step2,3...: images through the IFU-NS-2, full frame readout with the CCD binned 1x1
The user will need to adjust the exposure time to be appropriate for a given target. Use the ITC to find the exposure time needed. A S/N>=10 is recommended for acquisition observations.
For targets fainter than R~18mag, imaging through the IFU will take too long. Instead a blind offset acquisition should be used. For more information on blind offsetting, please see http://www.gemini.edu/sciops/telescopes-and-sites/acquisition-hardware-and-techniques/acquisition-techniques. For help setting up the acquistion, see the Description note for the "Longslit Acquisition (Blind Offset)" within the Templates: Spectroscopy Acquisition Observations folder. If it is not possible to find a nearby reference star with well known coordinates for blind offsetting, make the 2nd step be another imaging exposure, such that the position of the target on the CCD in imaging mode can be checked after the initial telescope offset has been determined and applied. The blind offset method is preferred because the user can directly measure from the acquisition image where the science target will approximately fall in the IFU field of view.

param.name: title
param.value: IFU N&S: Science with GCALflats - spectral dithering, no spatial offsetss

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This example of an IFU N&S science observation with GCAL flats mixed in.
Two spectral dither settings are used. It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
The number of shuffle rows for the IFU is 285.
The observation contain 1 science exposure and 1 GCALflat at each of 2 wavelength settings, 780nm and 785nm. Two wavelength settings is used to cover the gap between the CCDs.
The telescope nods to a sky position 15 arcseconds from the target. Since no objects are at the sky position the guiding is turned off there (OIWFS = freeze). This saves the overhead of waiting for the OI probe arm to move.
Assumed Conditions: IQ=70%, CC=50%, SB=50%, WV=Any (good IQ, photometric, dark)

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This is an IFU CuAr arc, to be taken as the baseline calibration during the day (class=Daytime Calibration).
Two spectral dither settings are used. It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
The guide star has been removed from the target component, since the telescope will be stationary at zenith for this observation.
The Translation Stage has been set to "Follow inZ Only" since the telescope is stationary and the Telescope Control System may not be up when this observation is taken.
The readout is "fast" in order to save time.

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This is an IFU N&S Dark, to be taken as the baseline calibration (class=Daytime Calibration).
The instrument is configured as following: disperser mirror, no FPU.
Each dark exposure consists of 15 N&S cycles (same as the science exposure). The total open shutter time is 1800sec per dark exposure in this example.
The guide star has been removed from the target component since the telescope will be stationary at zenith for this observation.
The Translation Stage has been set to "Do not follow" since the telescope is stationary and the Telescope Control System may not be up when this observation is taken.
Nod & Shuffle Darks will be taken on a best-effort basis when the telescope is closed for bad weather.
Number of Nod & Shuffle observations is set to 15.

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This example shows an IFU twilight flat, to be taken as the baseline calibration (class=Daytime Calibration).
It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
The guide star has been removed from the target component, since twilight flats are taken at blank fields and without guiding. There is no reason to enter the actual coordinates of the blank field.
For programs with multiple wavelength settings used to span the gaps between the CCDs, only one of these wavelength settings will have a twilight flat taken.
The exposure time is set to 30sec in the GMOS sequence. This makes it easy for the observer to adjust it as needed for the brightness of the sky.
The exposure is taken on the sky so the Translation stage should be 'Follow in X, Y, and Z (focus)'.

param.name: title
param.value: IFU N&S: Baseline Standard CuAr arc

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
- This example shows an IFU N&S CuAr arc, to be taken as the baseline calibration during the day (class=Daytime Calibration) for Baseline Standard.
- The guide star has been removed from the target component, since the telescope will be stationary at zenith for this observation.
- The Translation Stage has been set to "Follow in Z Only" since the telescope is stationary and the Telescope Control System may not be up when this observation is taken.
- The readout is "fast" in order to save time.
- The GMOS sequence that sequences the wavelength setting is the same as for the science observation such that arcs are taken at both wavelengths. The observation contain 2 wavelength settings, used to cover the gap between the CCDs and get full wavelength coverage.

param.name: title
param.value: IFU N&S: Baseline Standard: acquisition observation

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This example shows an acquisition observation for an IFU Baseline standard observation. It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
The class has been set to 'Acquisition Calibration'.
There is no target component as an appropriate target will be supplied by the Gemini observing staff when it is convenient to observe the spectrophotometric baseline standards.
The FPU, ROI, binning and exposure time are sequenced. Step1: imaging exposure with the CCD binned 2x2 Step2,3...: images through the IFU-NS-2, full frame readout with the CCD binned 1x1
The user may need to adjust the exposure times of the first and second steps as appropriate for their science target. Use the ITC to find the exposure time needed. A S/N>=10 is recommended for acquisition observations. The exposure time of the slit image (second step) should be left as defined at 10 seconds.

param.name: title
param.value: IFU N&S: Baseline Standard: observation with GCALflats

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This is an IFU Basecalib standard observation with GCAL flats mixed in.
The class of the observes is 'Nghttime Partner Calibration'.
It is assumed that GMOS is mounted on the side-looking ISS port.
The observation contain 1 science exposure and 1 GCALflat at each of 2 wavelength settings, 780nm and 785nm. Two wavelength settings is used to cover the gap between the CCDs and get full wavelength coverage. Instead of using one GMOS sequence, 2 sequences are used. This makes it possible to order the exposures as follows: science at 780nm GCALflat at 780nm GCALflat at 785nm science at 785nm
